fields.Title of Contribution: Cavity enhanced superradiant antennas for coherent<br>interconversion of photonic and Frenkel excitonic states
fields.Journal: Physical Review A-Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
fields.Description/Abstract: In order for a dye aggregate to function as a coherent quantum gate, the<br>excitonic state must pass through the gate on a time scale that is fast<br>compared to the exciton dephasing time. For the case when the input<br>and output are to be delivered as photonic states this also<br>necessitates antennas capable of intercoverting excitonic and photonic<br>states on a time scale that is fast compared to the exciton dephasing<br>time. Here we present an antenna architecture that, according to<br>Frenkel exciton theory, can achieve such rapid intercoversion. The<br>architecture consists of a superradiant antenna embedded within in a<br>microcavity. Coherent communication between gate input or output ports<br>and the large number of molecules constituting the superradiant antenna<br>is facilitated by a ramified exciton transmission-line network. The<br>combination of superradiant enhancement and Purcell enhancement by the<br>microcavity enables the emission or absorption rate of the antenna to<br>be 10$^5$ faster than the spontaneous emission rate of a single dye for<br>a realistic aggregate and microcavity design.
